content.title: Hemorrhagic Stroke (Intracerebral Hemorrhage)
content.summary: Spontaneous bleeding into brain parenchyma, most commonly from hypertensive arteriopathy
key_points: 15-20% of all strokes; higher mortality than ischemic
Hypertension is #1 cause; also CAA, AVM, anticoagulation
CT head shows hyperdense (white) lesion acutely
Aggressive BP reduction to SBP <140 within 1 hour (INTERACT2)

statement.text: Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is spontaneous bleeding into brain parenchyma, most commonly from rupture of small penetrating arteries damaged by chronic hypertension. Management focuses on BP reduction, anticoagulation reversal, and prevention of hematoma expansion.
statement.formal: ICH = Sudden focal deficit + CT hyperdensity in parenchyma → BP control to SBP <140 + Reverse anticoagulation + Monitor for expansion

explanation.intuition: A hemorrhagic stroke is a blood vessel bursting inside the brain, spilling blood into brain tissue. Unlike ischemic stroke, the problem isn't blockage - it's leakage. The blood acts like a mass, compressing and damaging brain tissue.
explanation.key_insight: Hematoma expansion in the first hours predicts poor outcome. The two treatable factors are BP (lowering reduces expansion) and anticoagulation reversal (restores clotting ability). Quick action matters.

definitions_glossary.intracerebral_hemorrhage: Spontaneous bleeding into brain parenchyma (not trauma-related)
definitions_glossary.hypertensive_hemorrhage: ICH from chronic HTN-related arteriopathy; typical locations: basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, cerebellum
definitions_glossary.cerebral_amyloid_angiopathy: Amyloid deposition in cortical vessels; causes lobar hemorrhage in elderly
definitions_glossary.hematoma_expansion: Growth of hemorrhage volume in first 24 hours; predicts worse outcomes
definitions_glossary.ICH_score: Prognostic score (0-6) predicting 30-day mortality based on GCS, volume, IVH, age, infratentorial location
definitions_glossary.mass_effect: Compression of adjacent brain structures by hematoma
definitions_glossary.intraventricular_hemorrhage: IVH - blood extending into ventricles; worsens prognosis
definitions_glossary.spot_sign: Contrast extravasation on CTA predicting hematoma expansion
definitions_glossary.reversal_agents: PCC, FFP, vitamin K (for warfarin); idarucizumab (dabigatran); andexanet al.fa (Xa inhibitors)
definitions_glossary.lobar_hemorrhage: Hemorrhage in cerebral cortex; suggests CAA or vascular malformation
definitions_glossary.deep_hemorrhage: Basal ganglia, thalamus, pons hemorrhage; typically hypertensive
definitions_glossary.Charcot_Bouchard_aneurysm: Microaneurysm in small penetrating arteries from chronic hypertension

pathophysiology.hypertensive_mechanism: Chronic HTN → lipohyalinosis of small penetrating arteries → microaneurysms (Charcot-Bouchard) → rupture
pathophysiology.CAA_mechanism: Amyloid-beta deposition in vessel walls → vessel fragility → lobar hemorrhage

clinical: Often with headache, decreased consciousness, vomiting
Rapid progression over minutes to hours

imaging.CT_head: Hyperdense (white) lesion in parenchyma; acute hemorrhage immediately visible
imaging.CT_angiography: Evaluate for underlying vascular malformation; 'spot sign' predicts expansion
imaging.MRI_GRE_SWI: Microbleeds suggest CAA or chronic hypertensive disease

blood_pressure.rationale: Reduces hematoma expansion without increasing ischemia

anticoagulation_reversal.warfarin: IV vitamin K 10mg + 4-factor PCC (25-50 U/kg); target INR <1.4

surgical_intervention.craniotomy: Consider for lobar hemorrhage with mass effect, cerebellar hemorrhage >3cm, declining consciousness

supportive: ICP monitoring and management if indicated

definition.@value: Spontaneous bleeding into brain parenchyma causing focal neurologic deficit and mass effect

learning_objectives: Distinguish ICH from ischemic stroke on CT
Apply rapid BP reduction to SBP <140
Select appropriate reversal agent for anticoagulation
clinical_pearls: ICH has higher mortality than ischemic stroke - quick BP control is critical
Spot sign on CTA = high risk of expansion - be aggressive
Lobar hemorrhage in elderly without HTN = think CAA
Cerebellar hemorrhage >3cm or with brainstem compression = surgical emergency
4-factor PCC reverses warfarin faster than FFP

sources.source: Hemphill JC, et al. AHA/ASA ICH Guideline 2015. Stroke 2015
